channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DATACMNS-292] Spring Data Repositories Cannot be used inside Advice w/ an AbstractAdvisorAutoProxyCreator
item.description:
This issue originally appeared on SEC-2136 and I believe it is related to DATAREST-53 but there is not enough information to be sure.

The issue occurs when a Spring Data repository is used in Advice and using AbstractAdvisorAutoProxyCreator. I have not had time to look into the issue in further detail, but intuition says that RepositoryInterfaceAwareBeanPostProcessor should implement AopInfrastructureBean.

I have attached a sample that demonstrates the issue happening and not happening with different permutations. You will notice there are a few samples that demonstrate Spring Security in use and a few that demonstrate without Spring Security.
item.summary: Spring Data Repositories Cannot be used inside Advice w/ an AbstractAdvisorAutoProxyCreator

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I should have included a stack example to make this easier to find:

	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.DefaultListableBeanFactory.raiseNoSuchBeanDefinitionException(DefaultListableBeanFactory.java:967)
 
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.DefaultListableBeanFactory.doResolveDependency(DefaultListableBeanFactory.java:837)
 
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.DefaultListableBeanFactory.resolveDependency(DefaultListableBeanFactory.java:749)

This can be closed as invalid per my comment on SEC-2136

Just to leave some clues why this works as it works on this side: Aspects, and especially beans referred to from aspects should refer to user components in a lazy way to avoid premature initialization of these beans. This is exactly what's happening here. We're creating a Spring Data JPA repository, the property population process in turn causes the EntityManagerFactory to be instantiated which is now suspect to the BeanostProcessor potentially creating the AOP proxy. This in turn now uses the infrastructure bean referring to the repository just about to be created.

There are generally a few options in this use case:

1. Injecting Provider<Foo> (from the @Inject standard) instead of Foo. This causes the actual lookup of the reference to be delayed until the client code calls get().
2. Manually creating an intermedia object through a ProxyFactoryBean using a LazyInitTargetSource (in the best case hidden behind some namespace element as Rob did in the Spring security case).
3. Injecting the bean name to refer to, implementing BeanFactoryAware and manually looking up the bean through factory on the first attempt (least preferable option).

The first option is probably the most preferable one as it works out of the box and also makes the lazy referral transparent, but requires an additional lookup step through get(). I've filed SPR-10353 to support the usage of @Lazy on injection points to automatically let the container create a ProxyFactoryBean with a LazyInitTargetSource (essentially automating approach 2).
